balinese.enphrase: Can I smoke in the room?
It is prohibited to smoke in the room.
It is permissible to smoke in your own room.
What facilities are provided in this villa?
balinese.fnphrase: Napi sarane sane wenten ring villa driki?

balinese.enphrase: Where is my room?
Where is the restaurant that is closest?
I am going to swim in the swimming pool.
Where is the pool for children?
He sleeps in the gazebo.
balinese.notes: This word is considered polite/proper.
balinese.fnphrase: Ida masirep ring bale bengong punika.

balinese.enphrase: Putu is enjoying a massage in the gazebo.
The guests are tanning by the swimming pool.
There is a tennis court in the back.
balinese.notes: This is an everyday form meaning "in the back." It comes from the words "di" (in) and "uri" (behind). The word "ungkur" is the more refined version.

balinese.enphrase: I am sitting on the beach.
balinese.notes: This in an everyday form, the more refined version is "malinggih."

balinese.enphrase: I am going to buy some fruit.
balinese.notes: This is the refined version. The more everyday form is "lakar".

balinese.enphrase: This snake fruit tastes very sweet.
balinese.notes: This is an everyday form of the word "very." It can also be used to mean "really?" in interrogatives, for example, Sajan I Made gelem? (Is Made really sick?)

balinese.enphrase: Could I have 1 kilo of grapes, please?
balinese.notes: This is a refined form. The more common form is "baang."

balinese.enphrase: Why is this so expensive?
balinese.notes: "Sanganan punika dados kaambil" (The cake can be taken.)

balinese.enphrase: This is not expensive.
balinese.notes: This form can be used in both formal and everday speech.

balinese.enphrase: It is already cheap.
balinese.notes: This is an everyday form, the more refined form is "murah" as in the sentence "Murah pisan pohe puniki" (The manggo is very cheap).

balinese.enphrase: Is there a cheaper one?
balinese.notes: This is a refined form, the moer common form is "ada."

balinese.enphrase: May I taste it?
balinese.notes: This is an everyday form.

balinese.enphrase: Please wrap up some fresh fruit for me.
balinese.notes: This is a refined form.
balinese.fnphrase: Bungkusang tiang woh-wohan sane seger manten.

balinese.enphrase: How much is it?
balinese.notes: In refined speech, "aji" means "father."

balinese.enphrase: I do not have any change.
balinese.notes: This is in common form, referring to money.

balinese.enphrase: How are you doing?
balinese.notes: This is in refined form. Literally, "What is the news?"

balinese.enphrase: Where is the Museum Neka located?
balinese.notes: This is refined form, the common form is "dija."
balinese.wordtype: ring: halus (alus mider), dija: biasa (kruna mider)

balinese.enphrase: Museum Neka is located in Kedewatan.
balinese.notes: This is the refined form, the more common form is "manongos."
balinese.fnphrase: Museum Neka nika taler magenah ring Kedewatan.

balinese.enphrase: What kind of collections do they have in there?
They have a collection of paintings.
They have a collection of carvings.
They have several collections writings.
I am going to visit the Museum Neka.
balinese.notes: This is the refined form, the more common form is "melali."
balinese.fnphrase: Tiang jagi malancaran ka Museum Neka.

balinese.enphrase: The famous painter was named Gusti Nyoman Lempad.
balinese.notes: This is the refined form. The more common form is "maadan."
balinese.fnphrase: Pelukis sane terkenal mawasta Gusti Nyoman Lempad.

balinese.enphrase: May I see his works?
balinese.notes: This is the refined form. The more common form is "nepukin."

balinese.enphrase: The paintings are really beautiful.
balinese.notes: This is the refined form. The more common form is "luwung."

balinese.enphrase: How are you doing, Grandpa?
balinese.notes: This is a refined form.

balinese.enphrase: Fine, how about you, Sari?
balinese.notes: This is the common form, the refined form is "punapi."

balinese.enphrase: I feel confused now, Grandpa.
Sure, I have heard about it.
balinese.notes: This is the common form, the refined form is "naenin."

balinese.enphrase: At a quiet and open space
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Ring genah sane ning tur embang

balinese.enphrase: I want to learn.
balinese.notes: The common word is "edot".

balinese.enphrase: I want to briefly ask something.
balinese.notes: The common word is "matakon".

balinese.enphrase: What is it that is important, Sari?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I want to learn yoga, older brother.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What is your name?
balinese.notes: Literally, "Who is your name?"

balinese.enphrase: Where will you go?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I will go to Kuta.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "titiyang".

balinese.enphrase: How are you?
balinese.notes: Literally, "What is the news?" was adopted from Indonesian.

balinese.enphrase: Very good.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "becik".

balinese.enphrase: Where are you from?
balinese.notes: The refined expression is "Saking napi?"

balinese.enphrase: I'm from America.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "saking".

balinese.enphrase: Are you married?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I'm already married.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "sampun".

balinese.enphrase: Indeed may all be well.
balinese.notes: Holy word used to begin prayers. "Om Swastiastu" is used as a greeting so that everyone present will be unharmed.

balinese.enphrase: Where are you traveling?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "mamargi".

balinese.enphrase: Going to the east.
balinese.notes: East is associated with holiness because it is the direction of the rising sun. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Going to the sea.
balinese.notes: South is associated with the ocean in South Bali but to the north in North Bali. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Going to the mountains.
balinese.notes: North is associated with the mountains in South Bali but to the south in North Bali. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Do you want take a taxi?
balinese.notes: The common word is "anggo".

balinese.enphrase: Going to the west.
balinese.notes: West is associated with death because it is the direction of the setting sun. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: He doesn't know the direction.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "uning".

balinese.enphrase: I am going to Besakih temple.
balinese.notes: This word is used for a Hindu holy place and used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I am going to school.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I am going to the pond.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I am going to the market.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "pasar."

balinese.enphrase: I am going to the mountain.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: May I be permitted to leave first?
balinese.notes: The common word for "asking to leave" is "mulih" (to return home)

balinese.enphrase: Is the taxi fare expensive?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Is it still far away?
balinese.notes: The common word is "joh".

balinese.enphrase: It's still very far.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "pisan".

balinese.enphrase: Where will you go now?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "pacang".

balinese.enphrase: Where are you going?
balinese.notes: The common word is "luas".

balinese.enphrase: Where is the bathroom?
balinese.notes: "Kamar kecil" (small room) is Indonesian. WC (way-say, from "water closet") is more commonly used.

balinese.enphrase: Yes, please go ahead.
balinese.notes: "Rarisang" is a refined word used to someone older, who you just met, or of high caste.

balinese.enphrase: Now it's the hot season.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What season is it now?
balinese.notes: The common word is "jani".

balinese.enphrase: Now it's the rainy season.
balinese.notes: The common word is "hujan".

balinese.enphrase: How long is the rainy season?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: How long is the hot season?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: The hot season makes the body sweat.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "kringet".
balinese.fnphrase: Masan panes ngae awake pesu peluh.

balinese.enphrase: When is the right time to harvest?
balinese.notes: This word refers to rice harvesting. For other kinds of harvests the word "alap" is used.
balinese.fnphrase: Masan napi nika becik anggen manyi?

balinese.enphrase: It's time to harvest when it's the cool season.
balinese.notes: This word is used in poetry and refined speech. The dry season is cool while the hot season is rainy.
balinese.fnphrase: Becik nika manyi ritatkala masan dingin.

balinese.enphrase: The river floods in the rainy season.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: During the rainy season it takes a long time to dry laundry.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Please try a bit of it.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I'd like to pay.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "naur."

balinese.enphrase: The cake is delicious.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What do you want to do?
balinese.notes: The common word is "lakar".

balinese.enphrase: I want to bathe.
balinese.notes: The common word is "mandus" or "manjus".

balinese.enphrase: I want to cook rice.
balinese.notes: This word refers to cooking rice. The common word is "nyakan".

balinese.enphrase: I want to pray in the temple.
balinese.notes: The common word is "mabakti".

balinese.enphrase: I want to plow the rice fields.
balinese.notes: This word refers to plowing rice fields with water buffalo, cattle, and traditional tools. The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I want to eat fried banana.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I want to put together an offering.
balinese.notes: This is the general term for "offering" of any type and material.

balinese.enphrase: I want to drink water.
balinese.notes: The common word is "yeh".

balinese.enphrase: I want to buy fruits.
balinese.notes: The common word is "meli".

balinese.enphrase: I want to sew a blouse.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I want to be purfied with holy water.
balinese.notes: This refers to ritual purification with holy water.

balinese.enphrase: I want to learn to dance.
balinese.notes: The very refined word "masolah" is reserved for divine beings and high caste people.

balinese.enphrase: I want to go to the market.
balinese.notes: The common word is "majalan."

balinese.translation: to drive or ride a vehicle
balinese.enphrase: I want to drive a motorcycle.
balinese.notes: This refers to sitting in a vehicle, from the word "tegak" (to sit). The Alus Singgih (high refined) word "malinggih" is for a divine being, senior, or high caste person and not oneself.

balinese.enphrase: Madam, do you have any tuna?
balinese.notes: The common word is "be".

balinese.enphrase: How much does one fish cost, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: The root word is "ukud" (tail) and is used for counting animals with tails.

balinese.enphrase: How about five thousand, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: May I buy two, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: The common word is "dadua."
balinese.fnphrase: Biang, tiang numbas kalih ukud, nggih?

balinese.enphrase: Do you have fresh fish, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: How much is one portion, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Can you give me 3 packages for 10,000 (rupiah)?
balinese.notes: This is used for a packet of something.
balinese.fnphrase: Napi icenin ja tigang tanding aji dasa tali, Biang?

balinese.enphrase: Do you have squid and shrimp, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: The common word is "muah".

balinese.enphrase: How much is the price of one kilo?
balinese.notes: Usually used with the word "kuda" (how much).

balinese.enphrase: Please give me half a kilo, Ma'am.
balinese.notes: The common word is "baang".
balinese.fnphrase: Icenin ampun pada atengan kilo, Biang.

balinese.enphrase: Here is the money, Ma'am.
balinese.notes: The common word is "pipis".

balinese.enphrase: You are welcome, Ma'am.
balinese.notes: Literally, "Thank you in return."

balinese.enphrase: What is your mother's name?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "wastan".

balinese.enphrase: My brother very much likes to eat.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "ngajeng".

balinese.enphrase: My grandmother is sick.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "sungkan".

balinese.enphrase: My older sister is on her way to school.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Embok titiange jagi mamargi ka sekolah.

balinese.enphrase: My father is a farmer.
balinese.notes: "Bapa" also is a term of respect for an older man.

balinese.enphrase: My wife is from Gianyar.
balinese.notes: The Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Why have you come here, Luh?
balinese.notes: The opposite word is "kema" (there).

balinese.enphrase: Can I help with the harvest?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I like Balinese calligraphy.
balinese.notes: A coined term for calligraphic writing of the Balinese alphabet.

balinese.enphrase: Emphasize the arm, abdominal and leg movements.
balinese.notes: The Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Utamane gerakan lengen, weteng lan cokor.

balinese.enphrase: What is the reason for that?
balinese.notes: The common word is "ulian".

balinese.enphrase: Yes, but don't force it.
balinese.notes: The root word is "paksa" and used in all levels.

balinese.enphrase: What else do I need to get ready?
balinese.notes: The root word is "siaga". The common word is "tragiang".

balinese.enphrase: Wear a shirt that is suitable and soft.
balinese.notes: The common word is "baju".
balinese.fnphrase: Anggen kuaca sane anut tur lemes.

balinese.enphrase: Which yoga movements are best for me to learn?
balinese.notes: The root word is "ajah" and used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Gerakan yoga napi sane patut kapelajahin titiang?

balinese.enphrase: Do I need to learn everything?
balinese.notes: The common word is "onyangan".

balinese.enphrase: First read this book on yoga.
balinese.notes: This is the imperative form of the root word "waca". The common word is "macen" from the root word "baca".

balinese.enphrase: Greetings, what is your name?
balinese.notes: The root word is "seng" and is Alus Singgih (high refined) used for seniors or high caste people and not for oneself. The common word is "adan".

balinese.enphrase: I'm Sari from Denpasar.
balinese.notes: The common word is "uli".

balinese.enphrase: Do you have a disease?
balinese.notes: The root word is "sungkan". The common word is "gelem".

balinese.enphrase: What medical treatments are available here?
balinese.notes: The root word is "usada", traditional Balinese healing in palm leaf manuscripts.

balinese.enphrase: There are a lot of plants here.
balinese.notes: The root word is "tandur" and used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Many kinds of plants are medicinal.
balinese.notes: The common word is "ubad" and used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Akeh sarwa entikan sane dados tamba.

balinese.enphrase: So is this from the medical palm leaf manuscript?
balinese.notes: The root word is "wit" and is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: The palm leaf manuscript of medicine is called Taru Pramana.
balinese.notes: Dried palm leaf manuscripts inscribed with Balinese letters and drawings.

balinese.enphrase: I thought there were only a few medical plants.
balinese.notes: The opposite word is "akeh."

balinese.enphrase: No, there are many ingredients that are mixed.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I was told I have a fever, is that right?
balinese.notes: The refined term is "sungkan panes".
balinese.fnphrase: Tiang kanawangang kena gelem panes, beneh?

balinese.enphrase: There are three kinds of diseases.
balinese.notes: The common word is "tatelu".

balinese.enphrase: What illness do I have?
balinese.notes: The common word is "kena".

balinese.enphrase: That building is also large.
balinese.notes: The common word is "gede".

balinese.enphrase: The water in the village is not polluted.
balinese.notes: The common word is "yeh".

balinese.enphrase: It is filtered through sand and gravel.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What is the way to process it?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Very suitable!
balinese.notes: The common word is "pesan".

balinese.enphrase: Use bamboo like this.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: This chocolate is organic.
balinese.notes: This is the short form of "puniki". The refined word for "that" is "punika" and shortened to "nika".

balinese.translation: to like, to feel happy about
balinese.enphrase: I like organic products.
balinese.notes: The common word is "demen".

balinese.enphrase: I like the bags containing nuts.
balinese.notes: The common word is "misi".
balinese.fnphrase: Titiang seneng bungkus sane medaging kacang.

balinese.enphrase: I like the salty ones.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I like the bitter ones.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I like the sweet ones.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: Are there other flavors?
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: Please taste this chocolate.
balinese.notes: The common word is "tegarang".

balinese.enphrase: The chocolate flavor is very good.
balinese.notes: The opposite word is "kaon" (bad).

balinese.enphrase: It does not contain preservatives.
balinese.notes: This is the short form of "nenten". The opposite word is "wenten" (to have).

balinese.enphrase: That was good!
balinese.notes: The refined word "puniki" or "niki" means "this".

balinese.enphrase: This way reduces waste.
balinese.notes: The root is "luu" and used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: It's difficult, right?
balinese.notes: The common word is "keweh".

balinese.enphrase: The harvest is tomorrow.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "benjang".

balinese.enphrase: The rice was eaten by birds.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "ring".

balinese.enphrase: The season cannot be predicted.
balinese.notes: The refined term is "ten uning".

balinese.enphrase: Yesterday we got ten sacks.
balinese.notes: The refined term is "di ibi".

balinese.enphrase: The hot season usually is six months.
balinese.notes: The word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: The rice crop is good.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "becik".

balinese.enphrase: How many shares do I get?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I want to learn how to harvest.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Who are you going with to the temple?
balinese.notes: The common word is "nyen".

balinese.enphrase: I am going there with my older sister.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Very good.
balinese.notes: The common word is "becik".

balinese.enphrase: One should know how to harvest.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Just how does one do the harvest?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "asapunapi".
balinese.fnphrase: Kenken dogen carane anak manyi ento?

balinese.enphrase: The people started harvesting three days ago.
balinese.notes: The refined term is "tigang rahina".
balinese.fnphrase: Uli telun anake sube mulai manyi.

balinese.enphrase: Where can one get purified in holy water?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Here is the place one gets purified with holy water.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "driki".

balinese.enphrase: It's for removing impurities from the body.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: In order to find inner peace and happiness.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Apang nemu kasukan lan padewekan nirmala.

balinese.enphrase: Oh it's like that, just now I know.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "titiyang".

balinese.enphrase: Have you requested holy water?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: May I request holy water?
balinese.notes: Sentence is usually spoken in the refined level. The common word is "ngidih".

balinese.enphrase: I want to pray first.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "muspa" from "puspa" (flower).

balinese.enphrase: Red and white are the colors of my flag.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Barak lan putih warnan benderan tiange.

balinese.enphrase: The black shirt is very good.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "pisan".
balinese.fnphrase: Baju ane selem ento melah gati.

balinese.enphrase: Mother is buying a white chicken.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "biang".

balinese.enphrase: Don't forget to wear a yellow shirt tomorrow.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "lali".
balinese.fnphrase: Ben mani eda engsap nganggo baju kuning.

balinese.enphrase: Please pick green vegetables, ok?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "jangan".

balinese.translation: to like, to be fond of
balinese.enphrase: My older sister likes red.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "seneng".

balinese.enphrase: The chocolate cake is delicious.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Jaja ane coklat ento jaen sajaan.

balinese.enphrase: Where have you come from?
balinese.notes: The common word is "teka".

balinese.enphrase: Can I ask something?
balinese.notes: The common word is "dadi".

balinese.enphrase: What can I help with?
balinese.notes: The common word is "mantu".

balinese.enphrase: Is there a vacant room here?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Napi wenten kamar sane suung driki?

balinese.enphrase: How long are you going to stay overnight?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels. The Alus Singgih (high refined) word "makolem" is for a divine being, senior, or high caste person and not for oneself.

balinese.enphrase: I already booked a room here.
balinese.notes: The common word is "suba".

balinese.enphrase: I am looking for two rooms.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "kekalih".

balinese.enphrase: Sorry, all the rooms are booked.
balinese.notes: The common word is "onyangan".
balinese.fnphrase: Ampura, kamare samian sampun wenten nak ngenahin.

balinese.enphrase: I'd like a room near a swimming pool.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "tampek" or "nampek".

balinese.enphrase: Can I smoke in the room?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "melanjaran".

balinese.enphrase: It is prohibited to smoke in the room.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: It is permissible to smoke in the room.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What facilities are provided in this villa?
balinese.notes: The common word is "apa".
balinese.fnphrase: Napi sarane sane wenten ring villa driki?

balinese.enphrase: Where is my room?
balinese.notes: The refined term is "ring dija".

balinese.enphrase: Where is the restaurant that is closest?
balinese.notes: The common term is "ane".

balinese.enphrase: I am going to swim in the swimming pool.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Where is the pool for children?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "alit".

balinese.enphrase: The lord is asleep in the gazebo.
balinese.notes: This Alus Singgih (high refined) word is used with the pronoun 'ida" for a divine being, senior, or high caste and not for oneself. The common word is "pules".
balinese.fnphrase: Ida masirep ring bale bengong punika.

balinese.enphrase: Putu is getting massaged in the gazebo.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: The guests are getting sunned by the pool.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: There is a tennis court in the back.
balinese.notes: This is from the words "di" (in) and "uri" (behind). The word "ungkur" is refined.

balinese.enphrase: I am sitting on the beach.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "malinggih."

balinese.enphrase: I want to buy fruits.
balinese.notes: The common word is "lakar".

balinese.enphrase: The snakeskin fruit tastes very sweet.
balinese.notes: This can also be used to mean "really?" in questions like, "Sajaan I Made gelem?" (Is Made really sick?)

balinese.enphrase: Could I have 1 kilo of grapes, please?
balinese.notes: The common word is "baang."

balinese.enphrase: Why is this so expensive?
balinese.notes: The common word is "dadi".

balinese.enphrase: This is not expensive.
balinese.notes: This word can be used in common and refined speech.

balinese.enphrase: This is already cheap.
balinese.notes: The common word is "mudah".

balinese.enphrase: Is there a cheaper one?
balinese.notes: The common word is "ada".

balinese.enphrase: May I taste it?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels. The Alus Singgih (high refined) word "ngedapin" is for senior or high caste people and not oneself.

balinese.enphrase: Please wrap up some fresh fruits for me.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Bungkusang titiang woh-wohan sane seger manten.

balinese.enphrase: How much is it?
balinese.notes: The refined word "aji" means "father".

balinese.enphrase: I do not have any change.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: How are you doing?
balinese.notes: Literally, "What is the news?"

balinese.enphrase: Where is the museum?
balinese.notes: "Ring dija" is a refined combination, the common word is "dija".

balinese.enphrase: The museum is located in Ubud.
balinese.notes: The common word is "matongos".

balinese.enphrase: What is there?
balinese.notes: The commong word is "ditu".

balinese.enphrase: They have a collection of paintings.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: They have a collection of carvings.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: They have a collection of literary works.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I am going to visit the museum.
balinese.notes: The common word is "melali".

balinese.enphrase: The famous painter was named Gusti Nyoman Lempad.
balinese.notes: The common word is "maadan".
balinese.fnphrase: Pelukis sane kasub mawasta Gusti Nyoman Lempad.

balinese.enphrase: May I see his works?
balinese.notes: The common word is "nyepukin".

balinese.enphrase: The paintings are really beautiful.
balinese.notes: The common word is "luung".

balinese.enphrase: Are you fine, Grandpa?
balinese.notes: This Alus Singgih (high refined) word is for a senior or high caste and not for oneself. The common word is "seger".

balinese.enphrase: Fine, how about you, Sari?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "asapunapi".

balinese.enphrase: I feel confused now, Grandpa.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels. The Alus Singgih (high refined) word "osek" is for a senior or high caste person and not for oneself.

balinese.enphrase: Yes I heard about it.
balinese.notes: The common word is "taen".
balinese.fnphrase: Nggih, titiyang naenin mirengin indik punika.

balinese.enphrase: At a quiet and open space
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Ring genah sane ning tur embang

balinese.enphrase: I want to learn.
balinese.notes: The common word is "edot".

balinese.enphrase: I want to briefly ask something.
balinese.notes: The common word is "matakon".

balinese.enphrase: What is it that is important, Sari?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I want to learn yoga, older brother.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What is your name?
balinese.notes: Literally, "Who is your name?"

balinese.enphrase: Where will you go?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I will go to Kuta.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "titiyang".

balinese.enphrase: How are you?
balinese.notes: Literally, "What is the news?" was adopted from Indonesian.

balinese.enphrase: Very good.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "becik".

balinese.enphrase: Where are you from?
balinese.notes: The refined expression is "Saking napi?"

balinese.enphrase: I'm from America.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "saking".

balinese.enphrase: Are you married?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I'm already married.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "sampun".

balinese.enphrase: Indeed may all be well.
balinese.notes: Holy word used to begin prayers. "Om Swastiastu" is used as a greeting so that everyone present will be unharmed.

balinese.enphrase: Where are you traveling?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "mamargi".

balinese.enphrase: Going to the east.
balinese.notes: East is associated with holiness because it is the direction of the rising sun. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Going to the sea.
balinese.notes: South is associated with the ocean in South Bali but to the north in North Bali. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Going to the mountains.
balinese.notes: North is associated with the mountains in South Bali but to the south in North Bali. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Do you want take a taxi?
balinese.notes: The common word is "anggo".

balinese.enphrase: Going to the west.
balinese.notes: West is associated with death because it is the direction of the setting sun. Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: He doesn't know the direction.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "uning".

balinese.enphrase: I am going to Besakih temple.
balinese.notes: This word is used for a Hindu holy place and used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I am going to school.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I am going to the pond.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I am going to the market.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "pasar."

balinese.enphrase: I am going to the mountain.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: May I be permitted to leave first?
balinese.notes: The common word for "asking to leave" is "mulih" (to return home)

balinese.enphrase: Is the taxi fare expensive?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Is it still far away?
balinese.notes: The common word is "joh".

balinese.enphrase: It's still very far.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "pisan".

balinese.enphrase: Where will you go now?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "pacang".

balinese.enphrase: Where are you going?
balinese.notes: The common word is "luas".

balinese.enphrase: Where is the bathroom?
balinese.notes: "Kamar kecil" (small room) is Indonesian. WC (way-say, from "water closet") is more commonly used.

balinese.enphrase: Yes, please go ahead.
balinese.notes: "Rarisang" is a refined word used to someone older, who you just met, or of high caste.

balinese.enphrase: Now it's the hot season.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What season is it now?
balinese.notes: The common word is "jani".

balinese.enphrase: Now it's the rainy season.
balinese.notes: The common word is "hujan".

balinese.enphrase: How long is the rainy season?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: How long is the hot season?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: The hot season makes the body sweat.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "kringet".
balinese.fnphrase: Masan panes ngae awake pesu peluh.

balinese.enphrase: When is the right time to harvest?
balinese.notes: This word refers to rice harvesting. For other kinds of harvests the word "alap" is used.
balinese.fnphrase: Masan napi nika becik anggen manyi?

balinese.enphrase: It's time to harvest when it's the cool season.
balinese.notes: This word is used in poetry and refined speech. The dry season is cool while the hot season is rainy.
balinese.fnphrase: Becik nika manyi ritatkala masan dingin.

balinese.enphrase: The river floods in the rainy season.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: During the rainy season it takes a long time to dry laundry.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Please try a bit of it.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I'd like to pay.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "naur."

balinese.enphrase: The cake is delicious.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What do you want to do?
balinese.notes: The common word is "lakar".

balinese.enphrase: I want to bathe.
balinese.notes: The common word is "mandus" or "manjus".

balinese.enphrase: I want to cook rice.
balinese.notes: This word refers to cooking rice. The common word is "nyakan".

balinese.enphrase: I want to pray in the temple.
balinese.notes: The common word is "mabakti".

balinese.enphrase: I want to plow the rice fields.
balinese.notes: This word refers to plowing rice fields with water buffalo, cattle, and traditional tools. The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I want to eat fried banana.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I want to put together an offering.
balinese.notes: This is the general term for "offering" of any type and material.

balinese.enphrase: I want to drink water.
balinese.notes: The common word is "yeh".

balinese.enphrase: I want to buy fruits.
balinese.notes: The common word is "meli".

balinese.enphrase: I want to sew a blouse.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I want to be purfied with holy water.
balinese.notes: This refers to ritual purification with holy water.

balinese.enphrase: I want to learn to dance.
balinese.notes: The very refined word "masolah" is reserved for divine beings and high caste people.

balinese.enphrase: I want to go to the market.
balinese.notes: The common word is "majalan."

balinese.translation: to drive or ride a vehicle
balinese.enphrase: I want to drive a motorcycle.
balinese.notes: This refers to sitting in a vehicle, from the word "tegak" (to sit). The Alus Singgih (high refined) word "malinggih" is for a divine being, senior, or high caste person and not oneself.

balinese.enphrase: Madam, do you have any tuna?
balinese.notes: The common word is "be".

balinese.enphrase: How much does one fish cost, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: The root word is "ukud" (tail) and is used for counting animals with tails.

balinese.enphrase: How about five thousand, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: May I buy two, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: The common word is "dadua."
balinese.fnphrase: Biang, tiang numbas kalih ukud, nggih?

balinese.enphrase: Do you have fresh fish, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: How much is one portion, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Can you give me 3 packages for 10,000 (rupiah)?
balinese.notes: This is used for a packet of something.
balinese.fnphrase: Napi icenin ja tigang tanding aji dasa tali, Biang?

balinese.enphrase: Do you have squid and shrimp, Ma'am?
balinese.notes: The common word is "muah".

balinese.enphrase: How much is the price of one kilo?
balinese.notes: Usually used with the word "kuda" (how much).

balinese.enphrase: Please give me half a kilo, Ma'am.
balinese.notes: The common word is "baang".
balinese.fnphrase: Icenin ampun pada atengan kilo, Biang.

balinese.enphrase: Here is the money, Ma'am.
balinese.notes: The common word is "pipis".

balinese.enphrase: You are welcome, Ma'am.
balinese.notes: Literally, "Thank you in return."

balinese.enphrase: What is your mother's name?
balinese.notes: The refined word is "wastan".

balinese.enphrase: My brother very much likes to eat.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "ngajeng".

balinese.enphrase: My grandmother is sick.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "sungkan".

balinese.enphrase: My older sister is on her way to school.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Embok titiange jagi mamargi ka sekolah.

balinese.enphrase: My father is a farmer.
balinese.notes: "Bapa" also is a term of respect for an older man.

balinese.enphrase: My wife is from Gianyar.
balinese.notes: The Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Why have you come here, Luh?
balinese.notes: The opposite word is "kema" (there).

balinese.enphrase: Can I help with the harvest?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I like Balinese calligraphy.
balinese.notes: A coined term for calligraphic writing of the Balinese alphabet.

balinese.enphrase: Emphasize the arm, abdominal and leg movements.
balinese.notes: The Word is used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Utamane gerakan lengen, weteng lan cokor.

balinese.enphrase: What is the reason for that?
balinese.notes: The common word is "ulian".

balinese.enphrase: Yes, but don't force it.
balinese.notes: The root word is "paksa" and used in all levels.

balinese.enphrase: What else do I need to get ready?
balinese.notes: The root word is "siaga". The common word is "tragiang".

balinese.enphrase: Wear a shirt that is suitable and soft.
balinese.notes: The common word is "baju".
balinese.fnphrase: Anggen kuaca sane anut tur lemes.

balinese.enphrase: Which yoga movements are best for me to learn?
balinese.notes: The root word is "ajah" and used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Gerakan yoga napi sane patut kapelajahin titiang?

balinese.enphrase: Do I need to learn everything?
balinese.notes: The common word is "onyangan".

balinese.enphrase: First read this book on yoga.
balinese.notes: This is the imperative form of the root word "waca". The common word is "macen" from the root word "baca".

balinese.enphrase: Greetings, what is your name?
balinese.notes: The root word is "seng" and is Alus Singgih (high refined) used for seniors or high caste people and not for oneself. The common word is "adan".

balinese.enphrase: I'm Sari from Denpasar.
balinese.notes: The common word is "uli".

balinese.enphrase: Do you have a disease?
balinese.notes: The root word is "sungkan". The common word is "gelem".

balinese.enphrase: What medical treatments are available here?
balinese.notes: The root word is "usada", traditional Balinese healing in palm leaf manuscripts.

balinese.enphrase: There are a lot of plants here.
balinese.notes: The root word is "tandur" and used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Many kinds of plants are medicinal.
balinese.notes: The common word is "ubad" and used in all speech levels.
balinese.fnphrase: Akeh sarwa entikan sane dados tamba.

balinese.enphrase: So is this from the medical palm leaf manuscript?
balinese.notes: The root word is "wit" and is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: The palm leaf manuscript of medicine is called Taru Pramana.
balinese.notes: Dried palm leaf manuscripts inscribed with Balinese letters and drawings.

balinese.enphrase: I thought there were only a few medical plants.
balinese.notes: The opposite word is "akeh."

balinese.enphrase: No, there are many ingredients that are mixed.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: I was told I have a fever, is that right?
balinese.notes: The refined term is "sungkan panes".
balinese.fnphrase: Tiang kanawangang kena gelem panes, beneh?

balinese.enphrase: There are three kinds of diseases.
balinese.notes: The common word is "tatelu".

balinese.enphrase: What illness do I have?
balinese.notes: The common word is "kena".

balinese.enphrase: That building is also large.
balinese.notes: The common word is "gede".

balinese.enphrase: The water in the village is not polluted.
balinese.notes: The common word is "yeh".

balinese.enphrase: It is filtered through sand and gravel.
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: What is the way to process it?
balinese.notes: Word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: Very suitable!
balinese.notes: The common word is "pesan".

balinese.enphrase: Use bamboo like this.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: This chocolate is organic.
balinese.notes: This is the short form of "puniki". The refined word for "that" is "punika" and shortened to "nika".

balinese.translation: to like, to feel happy about
balinese.enphrase: I like organic products.
balinese.notes: The common word is "demen".

balinese.enphrase: I like the bags containing nuts.
balinese.notes: The common word is "misi".
balinese.fnphrase: Titiang seneng bungkus sane medaging kacang.

balinese.enphrase: I like the salty ones.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I like the bitter ones.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: I like the sweet ones.
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: Are there other flavors?
balinese.notes: The sentence level is alus (refined).

balinese.enphrase: Please taste this chocolate.
balinese.notes: The common word is "tegarang".

balinese.enphrase: The chocolate flavor is very good.
balinese.notes: The opposite word is "kaon" (bad).

balinese.enphrase: It does not contain preservatives.
balinese.notes: This is the short form of "nenten". The opposite word is "wenten" (to have).

balinese.enphrase: That was good!
balinese.notes: The refined word "puniki" or "niki" means "this".

balinese.enphrase: This way reduces waste.
balinese.notes: The root is "luu" and used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: It's difficult, right?
balinese.notes: The common word is "keweh".

balinese.enphrase: The harvest is tomorrow.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "benjang".

balinese.enphrase: The rice was eaten by birds.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "ring".

balinese.enphrase: The season cannot be predicted.
balinese.notes: The refined term is "ten uning".

balinese.enphrase: Yesterday we got ten sacks.
balinese.notes: The refined term is "di ibi".

balinese.enphrase: The hot season usually is six months.
balinese.notes: The word is used in all speech levels.

balinese.enphrase: The rice crop is good.
balinese.notes: The refined word is "becik".
